ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
The seminar was held virtually over Zoom every week.
Only live visual lectures.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: history of Quebec and Canada from 1791-present, franco & cajun culture, Canadian relationships with other countries and within French and English Canadians
Learned about the history of Quebec and Canada. The class also developed critical thinking skills ("how to think like a historian").
I learned a lot about French Canadian history and the issues surrounding French Canadian identity.
A very thorough understanding of Canadian history and how to think and write like a historian.

Through this course, I built a knowledge of the history of Canada, particularly focusing on French Canada and Quebec, as well as French history in other parts of North America, such as Cajun history in Louisiana.

Canadian and Quebecois history! It was fascinating to learn about a different perspective and culture which is only a mere car ride away. Although I have always thought Canada was just a simple northern neighbor, I now know that it too had its own share of ethnic, religious, and political conflicts that still have impacts on life today.
In this course I learned about the history of Canada, specifically Quebec.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Many discussions, presentations, fun lectures

Virtual lectures with Professor Gitlin are the highlight of this course. He's so passionate about history and taught us so much more beyond the readings! His seminars are never boring - he really knows how to keep the pace going and he tells jokes and gives very fun historical anecdotes.

The class material was really interesting. The readings are a bit much, but they are manageable if you focus on the more important readings and skimming the rest. Prof G provided a lot of supplementary information that was really interesting and put the class in context.
Prof G kep the class very engaging. The readings were a bit boring, but I'm not a history major so that might be why. The prof went over all the important facts during class anyways.
Strengths: Professor Gitlin's style and enthusiasm, covering content that is not covered in many classes, learning how to write

Strengths- Prof. Jay Gitlin is amazing, the format is engaging, readings are very interesting, and discussions always lively.

Weaknesses- with so few assignments, it may be hard to know where your grade stands in the course, but a discussion with Prof. G will let you know where you are at
I loved this course, but I think the one area that can be improved is with the zoom seminars. It would have been better if it were in-person, but I understand given the circumstances.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Live sessions via Zoom
It didn't seem as though there was anything missing from the class by moving online, except for a few class field trips.

The Zoom seminar meetings worked surprisingly well.  There is no doubt that an in-person format would have likely been a little smoother and easier to facilitate lively discussion, but our class had no problem doing this virtually.
I think a socially-distance in-person seminar would have been nice to have and doable given the small size of the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, professor is great, passionate, and fun! You get to learn a lot about the Canadian history, people, and culture.
Yes! Definitely take this course if you are looking for a fun and engaging seminar and are curious to learn more about Quebec and Canada in general.
Yes, if the topic interests you! Prof G is definitely passionate about the subject, and his enthusiasm rubs off on his students.
Yes, Prof G is the jolliest man I have ever met. He brings such energy and joy to each class. Super chill and just loves anything that relates to Canada.

Absolutely recommend. This is a fantastic way to get a writing credit and be inspired by one of the best history professors at Yale. Even if you don't like history, any interest in Canada or any interest in improving your writing will make this class worth it.
I would highly recommend this course to any student interested in Canadian history.  It is a subject that is often ignored, but filled with an incredible amount of noteworthy events and movements.
Yes! Take it for Jay Gitlin. He is absolutely wonderful, and his passion for Canadian history is contagious. You will look forward to every class.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in Canadian history.
